message.body: Hello, franny. Is this a good time to chat?
Hey Jurgen, yes it is. Hows ur day so far?
Oh, the usual slow start. Reading last night and late to bed, but at least I'm enjoying the book. Today, up, check weather, find clothes, eat, grab lunc
h bag, and off on the trolley. You?
Im off to NY - just got on the bus. What book r u reading? And where r u off to?
/procedural/noir, I guess. My sister was done with it and gave it to me. I don't usually read things like this, but she assured me it was good, & it is.
Oh I'm at work now. That was just the start of the day. I work at the LDC so this chat is actually for work! :-) The book is COLD MOON. It's a mystery
You going on vacation?
Cool! Never heard of the book but genre sounds interesting. No, im off to a meeting with my advisors:) im a grad student. Hows working for LDC?
Besides being able to chat and feel productive about it :)
What's your field?
Linguistics.
Yeah? Yeah! What in particular?
Syntax, psycho .. What about u? R u a grad student as well?
t my Ph D work was on ASL.
Heh. No, I'm staff here. Official title is Research administrator. I've worked on various projects. I was a grad at Berkeley studying w both Lakoffs, bu
How do u like your work? When did you graduate?
great years at Dragon Systems, and then down here.
Graduated 1981, did a postdoc at Northeastern with Harlan Lane. Then a short stint in a research lab, about 6 years at Honeywell as a programmer, 10-11
Ergo, retirement.
I like my work fine, most of it. Problem is, it's all grant-funded, and in this financial & Congressional climate I haven't been able to get grants. :-(
That's a bummer. So your work is more 'computer-oriented', right?
mostly, these days, it's writing & checking. Well, including formatting. But I'm working with language, and I like that.
Not really. No way could I call myself a programmer now. I _use_ computers constantly, and I do some scratch programming to sort and track my data. But
ψlx… what kind? I haven't followed that very much.
What type of research did you do in the lab you mentioned earlier?
Just after the postdoc? That wasn't research at all, but assembler programming for a faculty member (Harvard? MIT?).
I see. Did u teach during the postdoc?
doing with "minicomputers" in the UCB Phonology lab for John Ohala.
There weren't many lx jobs around then. I applied around, and got hired as a "Senior Systems Programmer" at Honeywell, on the basis of the work I'd been
Oh, I just saw yr 2nd q. Yes, I taught a little.
Did u like that? Do u prefer research over teaching?
For someone else, it could be just the opposite.
Are you thinking about what it'll be like after school?
Ah. Speaking of multitasking, I have to get on with my main work now. But I'll be happy to continue this evening. Give me a buzz around 7, if you like.
Sure. Thanks! Enjoy your work
